Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! The data is processed and displayed both locally on a 128x64 OLED screen and remotely via a WiFi-based HTML dashboard with a clean, auto-refreshing UI. âš™ï¸ Key Features & Functionalities:âœ… Accurate sensor readings with analog signal smoothing and temperature compensation âœ… TDS and EC calculations based on real-time temperature feedback âœ… OLED Display showing TDS, EC, temperature (Â°C), and device IP address âœ… Responsive Web Dashboard hosted on the ESP32 with HTML + CSS for mobile and desktop viewing âœ… Static IP configuration for consistent access over local network âœ… Built-in HTTP server on port 80 for real-time monitoring via any browser âœ… Temperature in both Â°C and Â°F, auto-calculated ğŸ–¥ï¸Tech Stack & Tools Used:1. Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Follow along and let's grow together. ğŸš€ğŸ”” Follow me to get these updates!ğŸ’¬ Which Java trick interests you most? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! The data is processed and displayed both locally on a 128x64 OLED screen and remotely via a WiFi-based HTML dashboard with a clean, auto-refreshing UI. âš™ï¸ Key Features & Functionalities:âœ… Accurate sensor readings with analog signal smoothing and temperature compensation âœ… TDS and EC calculations based on real-time temperature feedback âœ… OLED Display showing TDS, EC, temperature (Â°C), and device IP address âœ… Responsive Web Dashboard hosted on the ESP32 with HTML + CSS for mobile and desktop viewing âœ… Static IP configuration for consistent access over local network âœ… Built-in HTTP server on port 80 for real-time monitoring via any browser âœ… Temperature in both Â°C and Â°F, auto-calculated ğŸ–¥ï¸Tech Stack & Tools Used:1. Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Long ago, when I started my journey as a developer, Java was the first serious language I committed to.It was trending.It was not â€œeasy.â€It demanded commitment with discipline.It raised the bar of programming standards.Back then, most of the people moving to Java were coming from C or C++ backgrounds. To be productive in C++, you had to be a good programmer, having good command on OOP concepts especially polymorphism. In addition to OOP, you couldnâ€™t fake your way through memory management, pointers, templates and object slicing. Java came in as a more structured, opinionated language, but still demanded solid fundamentals just like C++. In fact, Iâ€™d argue, and IMHO, you rarely see an average programmer doing good in Java. It exposes gaps in your thoughts, and demand a better programming aptitude, not just for syntax, but also for development design especially taking ownership of your code with integration & unit tests.Java developers are often rated as having stronger software engineering and system design skills in hiring benchmarks, especially in enterprise and backend domains.Java doesnâ€™t teach you to just get things done. It teaches you how to think, how to structure, and how to build something that wonâ€™t collapse six months from now.I happily admit and gives credit to Java for my growth, it taught me: - Real-world modeling with OOP & OOAD - Contracts matter with method overloading & overriding (Polymorphism) - Building objects relationships in real world based on class hierarchy using inheritance or object agregation or composition based on loose or tight coupling. - Abstraction & encapsulation to write better code visibility & reusability. - Think yout code by applying design patterns especially "Gang of Four" & design principles like SOLID, KISS, DRY, YAGNI or etc. - The power of the JVM and why type safety matters at scaleAfter working across Pakistan, Japan, US (Remote) and Germany, leading engineering at global companies, migrating systems to the cloud, and building scalable platforms. I still find Javaâ€™s influence in how I think and design. Itâ€™s a legacy of good practises in action.A Stack Overflow Developer Survey still places Java among the most used and loved backend languages, even with all the new frameworks and languages in the ecosystem.For new learners or budding programmers, donâ€™t be discouraged by its rules or verbosity. Those same things will shape you into a better software engineer.Build systems, but also build your legacy.hashtag#java hashtag#programming hashtag#softwaredevelopment hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#developermindset hashtag#techleadership hashtag#cleancode hashtag#engineeringgrowth hashtag#growthmindset hashtag#objectorienteddesign hashtag#objectorientedprogramming hashtag#softwarecraftsmanship hashtag#lifelonglearner

If you're a new document controller, here are some practical tips to help you grow faster, avoid common mistakes, and earn the trust of your team:âœ… 1. Understand the Project Structure FirstBefore diving into filing documents, take time to understand the project's phases, key disciplines, and document types. This makes organizing and tagging much easier.âœ… 2. Naming Conventions Are Not Just FormalitiesFollow them strictly. They're essential for traceability and version controlâ€”and can save hours during audits or disputes.âœ… 3. Keep Your Registers Clean and UpdatedWhether you're using Excel or an EDMS, your logs are the heart of document tracking. Incomplete logs cause confusionâ€”be diligent.âœ… 4. Communicate with Engineers and DesignersYou're not just pushing papers. You're managing information flow. Ask questions, clarify document statuses, and don't hesitate to request re-submissions if something doesn't follow procedure.âœ… 5. Learn the Tools DeeplyDonâ€™t just "use" Aconex or Omega365â€”master it. Explore shortcuts, batch processing, and advanced features to save time and reduce errors.âœ… 6. Always Back Up. Always.Even with cloud systems, keep daily backups of registers and key documents. Technology failsâ€”discipline doesnâ€™t.âœ… 7. Be the Guardian of ComplianceYour role ensures that the right people get the right information at the right timeâ€”with full traceability. Thatâ€™s powerful.ğŸ¯ To all the fresh document controllers out there: Your job may feel behind-the-scenes, but your work is what holds a project together. When NVS Fails on ESP32â€¦ LittleFS to the Rescue! In one of our recent IoT projects, we ran into a tricky issue after rolling out a new firmware update (OTA) to all our ESP32-based devices. Out of nearly 30,000 units, about 100 started acting weirdâ€”some configs didnâ€™t load properly, and things just didnâ€™t add up.After digging into it, we found the root cause: we had increased the EEPROM size from 2KB to 5KB, and it turned out NVS couldnâ€™t handle it well on all devices.When we scanned the full memory, we saw corruption issues in those affected devices. ğŸ˜¬So, together with my teammates, we decided to shift our strategy.We moved our data and device configurations from NVS to SPIFFS using LittleFS ---> and it worked like a charm! ğŸ‹  Everything became stable and clean again.ğŸ” A quick takeaway:Sometimes NVS isn't the best fit for larger or dynamic data. LittleFS gave us the reliability we needed for this scale of deployment.Just wanted to share in case someone else is hitting a similar wallâ€”hope it saves you some time!hashtag#ESP32 hashtag#IoT hashtag#LittleFS hashtag#NVS hashtag#SPIFFS hashtag#FirmwareUpdate hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MemoryManagement hashtag#TechFix

Long ago, when I started my journey as a developer, Java was the first serious language I committed to.It was trending.It was not â€œeasy.â€It demanded commitment with discipline.It raised the bar of programming standards.Back then, most of the people moving to Java were coming from C or C++ backgrounds. To be productive in C++, you had to be a good programmer, having good command on OOP concepts especially polymorphism. In addition to OOP, you couldnâ€™t fake your way through memory management, pointers, templates and object slicing. Java came in as a more structured, opinionated language, but still demanded solid fundamentals just like C++. In fact, Iâ€™d argue, and IMHO, you rarely see an average programmer doing good in Java. It exposes gaps in your thoughts, and demand a better programming aptitude, not just for syntax, but also for development design especially taking ownership of your code with integration & unit tests.Java developers are often rated as having stronger software engineering and system design skills in hiring benchmarks, especially in enterprise and backend domains.Java doesnâ€™t teach you to just get things done. It teaches you how to think, how to structure, and how to build something that wonâ€™t collapse six months from now.I happily admit and gives credit to Java for my growth, it taught me: - Real-world modeling with OOP & OOAD - Contracts matter with method overloading & overriding (Polymorphism) - Building objects relationships in real world based on class hierarchy using inheritance or object agregation or composition based on loose or tight coupling. - Abstraction & encapsulation to write better code visibility & reusability. - Think yout code by applying design patterns especially "Gang of Four" & design principles like SOLID, KISS, DRY, YAGNI or etc. - The power of the JVM and why type safety matters at scaleAfter working across Pakistan, Japan, US (Remote) and Germany, leading engineering at global companies, migrating systems to the cloud, and building scalable platforms. I still find Javaâ€™s influence in how I think and design. Itâ€™s a legacy of good practises in action.A Stack Overflow Developer Survey still places Java among the most used and loved backend languages, even with all the new frameworks and languages in the ecosystem.For new learners or budding programmers, donâ€™t be discouraged by its rules or verbosity. Those same things will shape you into a better software engineer.Build systems, but also build your legacy.hashtag#java hashtag#programming hashtag#softwaredevelopment hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#developermindset hashtag#techleadership hashtag#cleancode hashtag#engineeringgrowth hashtag#growthmindset hashtag#objectorienteddesign hashtag#objectorientedprogramming hashtag#softwarecraftsmanship hashtag#lifelonglearner

If you're a new document controller, here are some practical tips to help you grow faster, avoid common mistakes, and earn the trust of your team:âœ… 1. Understand the Project Structure FirstBefore diving into filing documents, take time to understand the project's phases, key disciplines, and document types. This makes organizing and tagging much easier.âœ… 2. Naming Conventions Are Not Just FormalitiesFollow them strictly. They're essential for traceability and version controlâ€”and can save hours during audits or disputes.âœ… 3. Keep Your Registers Clean and UpdatedWhether you're using Excel or an EDMS, your logs are the heart of document tracking. Incomplete logs cause confusionâ€”be diligent.âœ… 4. Communicate with Engineers and DesignersYou're not just pushing papers. You're managing information flow. Ask questions, clarify document statuses, and don't hesitate to request re-submissions if something doesn't follow procedure.âœ… 5. Learn the Tools DeeplyDonâ€™t just "use" Aconex or Omega365â€”master it. Explore shortcuts, batch processing, and advanced features to save time and reduce errors.âœ… 6. Always Back Up. Always.Even with cloud systems, keep daily backups of registers and key documents. Technology failsâ€”discipline doesnâ€™t.âœ… 7. Be the Guardian of ComplianceYour role ensures that the right people get the right information at the right timeâ€”with full traceability. Thatâ€™s powerful.ğŸ¯ To all the fresh document controllers out there: Your job may feel behind-the-scenes, but your work is what holds a project together. Own it.hashtag#DocumentControl hashtag#ConstructionManagement hashtag#Omega365 hashtag#Aconex hashtag#Procore hashtag#CareerAdvice hashtag#ProjectManagement hashtag#EDMS

When NVS Fails on ESP32â€¦ LittleFS to the Rescue! In one of our recent IoT projects, we ran into a tricky issue after rolling out a new firmware update (OTA) to all our ESP32-based devices. Out of nearly 30,000 units, about 100 started acting weirdâ€”some configs didnâ€™t load properly, and things just didnâ€™t add up.After digging into it, we found the root cause: we had increased the EEPROM size from 2KB to 5KB, and it turned out NVS couldnâ€™t handle it well on all devices.When we scanned the full memory, we saw corruption issues in those affected devices. ğŸ˜¬So, together with my teammates, we decided to shift our strategy.We moved our data and device configurations from NVS to SPIFFS using LittleFS ---> and it worked like a charm! ğŸ‹  Everything became stable and clean again.ğŸ” A quick takeaway:Sometimes NVS isn't the best fit for larger or dynamic data. LittleFS gave us the reliability we needed for this scale of deployment.Just wanted to share in case someone else is hitting a similar wallâ€”hope it saves you some time!hashtag#ESP32 hashtag#IoT hashtag#LittleFS hashtag#NVS hashtag#SPIFFS hashtag#FirmwareUpdate hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MemoryManagement hashtag#TechFix

"ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙÙ„ Ø±ÙÙ‘Ø¨ÙÙ‘ Ø²ÙØ¯Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù‹Ø§" â€“ Ø³ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø·Ù‡ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© 114ğŸ”§ MCSA Project 5: Deploying a Multi-Site Domain Controller with IFM and NIC Teaming â€“ A Real-World SimulationIâ€™ve just completed my fifth and most comprehensive MCSA project so far â€” a full-scale enterprise-level deployment involving multiple sites, advanced domain replication, and optimized server communication. Here's a breakdown of what I implemented:1ï¸âƒ£ Creating IFM Media for Domain Replication To simulate a real-world "Install From Media" (IFM) scenario, I generated a custom IFM package containing the Active Directory database and SYSVOL. Using ntdsutil via elevated CMD, I navigated to the IFM module and executed the command: create sysvol full C:\ifm This IFM folder allows a new domain controller to be promoted without replicating over the WAN â€” ideal for branch offices.2ï¸âƒ£ Lab Structure and Configuration I designed two sites: Cairo and Mansoura.Cairoâ€™s Server 2016 was configured as a Primary Domain Controller (PDC) and joined with a Windows 10 client in the same domain.The network was fully connected (pingable), and proper domain resolution was ensured through DNS configuration.I added a second Ethernet adapter and implemented NIC Teaming, enhancing bandwidth and redundancy.ğŸ’¡ NIC Teaming Benefits:Increased throughput via load balancingNetwork fault toleranceSeamless connectivity in case of NIC failure3ï¸âƒ£ Cloning and SID Regeneration for New Site To prepare the Mansoura site, I cloned the Cairo server and changed its SID using Sysprep to avoid domain conflicts. Upon reboot, the server was demoted to a Workgroup â€” a critical step in separating domain identity between sites.4ï¸âƒ£ Establishing Trust & Promoting the ADCI reconnected the Mansoura server to the Cairo network.Ensured two-way communication was functional (DNS + pingable).Installed Active Directory Domain Services on Mansoura's server.Promoted it as an Additional Domain Controller (ADC) using credentials from the existing domain (tshoot\administrator).Selected Mansoura as the site and enabled both DNS and Global Catalog roles.5ï¸âƒ£ IFM-Based User Replication Post-promotion, I imported the users from the previously created IFM folder. âœ… Users created in Cairo were instantly visible in Mansoura â€” proving successful replication.6ï¸âƒ£ Final TouchesRenamed servers accordingly: PDC (Cairo) and ADC (Mansoura)Disabled firewalls to avoid blocking replication or communicationInstalled VMware Tools to enhance performance and integrationğŸ’¼ This project was a deep dive into multi-site domain architecture, replication, network optimization, and disaster recovery readiness â€” and honestly, it felt like managing an enterprise-level infrastructure.Always striving to learn by doing, and this one was a milestone.Mohamed Tarek Zyad Waleed Elzyat Ali Khaled hashtag#MCSA hashtag#ActiveDirectory hashtag#Sysadmin hashtag#WindowsServer2016 hashtag#Networking hashtag#ITInfrastructure hashtag#NICTeaming hashtag#InstallFromMedia hashtag#LinkedInLearning hashtag#SysadminLife hashtag#MCSE hashtag#ITProjects

Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Long ago, when I started my journey as a developer, Java was the first serious language I committed to.It was trending.It was not â€œeasy.â€It demanded commitment with discipline.It raised the bar of programming standards.Back then, most of the people moving to Java were coming from C or C++ backgrounds. To be productive in C++, you had to be a good programmer, having good command on OOP concepts especially polymorphism. In addition to OOP, you couldnâ€™t fake your way through memory management, pointers, templates and object slicing. Java came in as a more structured, opinionated language, but still demanded solid fundamentals just like C++. In fact, Iâ€™d argue, and IMHO, you rarely see an average programmer doing good in Java. It exposes gaps in your thoughts, and demand a better programming aptitude, not just for syntax, but also for development design especially taking ownership of your code with integration & unit tests.Java developers are often rated as having stronger software engineering and system design skills in hiring benchmarks, especially in enterprise and backend domains.Java doesnâ€™t teach you to just get things done. It teaches you how to think, how to structure, and how to build something that wonâ€™t collapse six months from now.I happily admit and gives credit to Java for my growth, it taught me: - Real-world modeling with OOP & OOAD - Contracts matter with method overloading & overriding (Polymorphism) - Building objects relationships in real world based on class hierarchy using inheritance or object agregation or composition based on loose or tight coupling. - Abstraction & encapsulation to write better code visibility & reusability. - Think yout code by applying design patterns especially "Gang of Four" & design principles like SOLID, KISS, DRY, YAGNI or etc. - The power of the JVM and why type safety matters at scaleAfter working across Pakistan, Japan, US (Remote) and Germany, leading engineering at global companies, migrating systems to the cloud, and building scalable platforms. I still find Javaâ€™s influence in how I think and design. Itâ€™s a legacy of good practises in action.A Stack Overflow Developer Survey still places Java among the most used and loved backend languages, even with all the new frameworks and languages in the ecosystem.For new learners or budding programmers, donâ€™t be discouraged by its rules or verbosity. Those same things will shape you into a better software engineer.Build systems, but also build your legacy.hashtag#java hashtag#programming hashtag#softwaredevelopment hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#developermindset hashtag#techleadership hashtag#cleancode hashtag#engineeringgrowth hashtag#growthmindset hashtag#objectorienteddesign hashtag#objectorientedprogramming hashtag#softwarecraftsmanship hashtag#lifelonglearner

If you're a new document controller, here are some practical tips to help you grow faster, avoid common mistakes, and earn the trust of your team:âœ… 1. Understand the Project Structure FirstBefore diving into filing documents, take time to understand the project's phases, key disciplines, and document types. This makes organizing and tagging much easier.âœ… 2. Naming Conventions Are Not Just FormalitiesFollow them strictly. They're essential for traceability and version controlâ€”and can save hours during audits or disputes.âœ… 3. Keep Your Registers Clean and UpdatedWhether you're using Excel or an EDMS, your logs are the heart of document tracking. Incomplete logs cause confusionâ€”be diligent.âœ… 4. Communicate with Engineers and DesignersYou're not just pushing papers. You're managing information flow. Ask questions, clarify document statuses, and don't hesitate to request re-submissions if something doesn't follow procedure.âœ… 5. Learn the Tools DeeplyDonâ€™t just "use" Aconex or Omega365â€”master it. Explore shortcuts, batch processing, and advanced features to save time and reduce errors.âœ… 6. Always Back Up. Always.Even with cloud systems, keep daily backups of registers and key documents. Technology failsâ€”discipline doesnâ€™t.âœ… 7. Be the Guardian of ComplianceYour role ensures that the right people get the right information at the right timeâ€”with full traceability. Thatâ€™s powerful.ğŸ¯ To all the fresh document controllers out there: Your job may feel behind-the-scenes, but your work is what holds a project together. When NVS Fails on ESP32â€¦ LittleFS to the Rescue! In one of our recent IoT projects, we ran into a tricky issue after rolling out a new firmware update (OTA) to all our ESP32-based devices. Out of nearly 30,000 units, about 100 started acting weirdâ€”some configs didnâ€™t load properly, and things just didnâ€™t add up.After digging into it, we found the root cause: we had increased the EEPROM size from 2KB to 5KB, and it turned out NVS couldnâ€™t handle it well on all devices.When we scanned the full memory, we saw corruption issues in those affected devices. ğŸ˜¬So, together with my teammates, we decided to shift our strategy.We moved our data and device configurations from NVS to SPIFFS using LittleFS ---> and it worked like a charm! ğŸ‹  Everything became stable and clean again.ğŸ” A quick takeaway:Sometimes NVS isn't the best fit for larger or dynamic data. LittleFS gave us the reliability we needed for this scale of deployment.Just wanted to share in case someone else is hitting a similar wallâ€”hope it saves you some time!hashtag#ESP32 hashtag#IoT hashtag#LittleFS hashtag#NVS hashtag#SPIFFS hashtag#FirmwareUpdate hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MemoryManagement hashtag#TechFix

"ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙÙ„ Ø±ÙÙ‘Ø¨ÙÙ‘ Ø²ÙØ¯Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù‹Ø§" â€“ Ø³ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø·Ù‡ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© 114ğŸ”§ MCSA Project 5: Deploying a Multi-Site Domain Controller with IFM and NIC Teaming â€“ A Real-World SimulationIâ€™ve just completed my fifth and most comprehensive MCSA project so far â€” a full-scale enterprise-level deployment involving multiple sites, advanced domain replication, and optimized server communication. Here's a breakdown of what I implemented:1ï¸âƒ£ Creating IFM Media for Domain Replication To simulate a real-world "Install From Media" (IFM) scenario, I generated a custom IFM package containing the Active Directory database and SYSVOL. Using ntdsutil via elevated CMD, I navigated to the IFM module and executed the command: create sysvol full C:\ifm This IFM folder allows a new domain controller to be promoted without replicating over the WAN â€” ideal for branch offices.2ï¸âƒ£ Lab Structure and Configuration I designed two sites: Cairo and Mansoura.Cairoâ€™s Server 2016 was configured as a Primary Domain Controller (PDC) and joined with a Windows 10 client in the same domain.The network was fully connected (pingable), and proper domain resolution was ensured through DNS configuration.I added a second Ethernet adapter and implemented NIC Teaming, enhancing bandwidth and redundancy.ğŸ’¡ NIC Teaming Benefits:Increased throughput via load balancingNetwork fault toleranceSeamless connectivity in case of NIC failure3ï¸âƒ£ Cloning and SID Regeneration for New Site To prepare the Mansoura site, I cloned the Cairo server and changed its SID using Sysprep to avoid domain conflicts. Upon reboot, the server was demoted to a Workgroup â€” a critical step in separating domain identity between sites.4ï¸âƒ£ Establishing Trust & Promoting the ADCI reconnected the Mansoura server to the Cairo network.Ensured two-way communication was functional (DNS + pingable).Installed Active Directory Domain Services on Mansoura's server.Promoted it as an Additional Domain Controller (ADC) using credentials from the existing domain (tshoot\administrator).Selected Mansoura as the site and enabled both DNS and Global Catalog roles.5ï¸âƒ£ IFM-Based User Replication Post-promotion, I imported the users from the previously created IFM folder. âœ… Users created in Cairo were instantly visible in Mansoura â€” proving successful replication.6ï¸âƒ£ Final TouchesRenamed servers accordingly: PDC (Cairo) and ADC (Mansoura)Disabled firewalls to avoid blocking replication or communicationInstalled VMware Tools to enhance performance and integrationğŸ’¼ This project was a deep dive into multi-site domain architecture, replication, network optimization, and disaster recovery readiness â€” and honestly, it felt like managing an enterprise-level infrastructure.Always striving to learn by doing, and this one was a milestone.Mohamed Tarek Zyad Waleed Elzyat Ali Khaled hashtag#MCSA hashtag#ActiveDirectory hashtag#Sysadmin hashtag#WindowsServer2016 hashtag#Networking hashtag#ITInfrastructure hashtag#NICTeaming hashtag#InstallFromMedia hashtag#LinkedInLearning hashtag#SysadminLife hashtag#MCSE hashtag#ITProjects

Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! The data is processed and displayed both locally on a 128x64 OLED screen and remotely via a WiFi-based HTML dashboard with a clean, auto-refreshing UI. âš™ï¸ Key Features & Functionalities:âœ… Accurate sensor readings with analog signal smoothing and temperature compensation âœ… TDS and EC calculations based on real-time temperature feedback âœ… OLED Display showing TDS, EC, temperature (Â°C), and device IP address âœ… Responsive Web Dashboard hosted on the ESP32 with HTML + CSS for mobile and desktop viewing âœ… Static IP configuration for consistent access over local network âœ… Built-in HTTP server on port 80 for real-time monitoring via any browser âœ… Temperature in both Â°C and Â°F, auto-calculated ğŸ–¥ï¸Tech Stack & Tools Used:1. Long ago, when I started my journey as a developer, Java was the first serious language I committed to.It was trending.It was not â€œeasy.â€It demanded commitment with discipline.It raised the bar of programming standards.Back then, most of the people moving to Java were coming from C or C++ backgrounds. To be productive in C++, you had to be a good programmer, having good command on OOP concepts especially polymorphism. In addition to OOP, you couldnâ€™t fake your way through memory management, pointers, templates and object slicing. Java came in as a more structured, opinionated language, but still demanded solid fundamentals just like C++. In fact, Iâ€™d argue, and IMHO, you rarely see an average programmer doing good in Java. It exposes gaps in your thoughts, and demand a better programming aptitude, not just for syntax, but also for development design especially taking ownership of your code with integration & unit tests.Java developers are often rated as having stronger software engineering and system design skills in hiring benchmarks, especially in enterprise and backend domains.Java doesnâ€™t teach you to just get things done. It teaches you how to think, how to structure, and how to build something that wonâ€™t collapse six months from now.I happily admit and gives credit to Java for my growth, it taught me: - Real-world modeling with OOP & OOAD - Contracts matter with method overloading & overriding (Polymorphism) - Building objects relationships in real world based on class hierarchy using inheritance or object agregation or composition based on loose or tight coupling. - Abstraction & encapsulation to write better code visibility & reusability. - Think yout code by applying design patterns especially "Gang of Four" & design principles like SOLID, KISS, DRY, YAGNI or etc. - The power of the JVM and why type safety matters at scaleAfter working across Pakistan, Japan, US (Remote) and Germany, leading engineering at global companies, migrating systems to the cloud, and building scalable platforms. I still find Javaâ€™s influence in how I think and design. Itâ€™s a legacy of good practises in action.A Stack Overflow Developer Survey still places Java among the most used and loved backend languages, even with all the new frameworks and languages in the ecosystem.For new learners or budding programmers, donâ€™t be discouraged by its rules or verbosity. Those same things will shape you into a better software engineer.Build systems, but also build your legacy.hashtag#java hashtag#programming hashtag#softwaredevelopment hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#developermindset hashtag#techleadership hashtag#cleancode hashtag#engineeringgrowth hashtag#growthmindset hashtag#objectorienteddesign hashtag#objectorientedprogramming hashtag#softwarecraftsmanship hashtag#lifelonglearner

If you're a new document controller, here are some practical tips to help you grow faster, avoid common mistakes, and earn the trust of your team:âœ… 1. Understand the Project Structure FirstBefore diving into filing documents, take time to understand the project's phases, key disciplines, and document types. This makes organizing and tagging much easier.âœ… 2. Naming Conventions Are Not Just FormalitiesFollow them strictly. They're essential for traceability and version controlâ€”and can save hours during audits or disputes.âœ… 3. Keep Your Registers Clean and UpdatedWhether you're using Excel or an EDMS, your logs are the heart of document tracking. Incomplete logs cause confusionâ€”be diligent.âœ… 4. Communicate with Engineers and DesignersYou're not just pushing papers. You're managing information flow. Ask questions, clarify document statuses, and don't hesitate to request re-submissions if something doesn't follow procedure.âœ… 5. Learn the Tools DeeplyDonâ€™t just "use" Aconex or Omega365â€”master it. Explore shortcuts, batch processing, and advanced features to save time and reduce errors.âœ… 6. Always Back Up. Always.Even with cloud systems, keep daily backups of registers and key documents. Technology failsâ€”discipline doesnâ€™t.âœ… 7. Be the Guardian of ComplianceYour role ensures that the right people get the right information at the right timeâ€”with full traceability. Thatâ€™s powerful.ğŸ¯ To all the fresh document controllers out there: Your job may feel behind-the-scenes, but your work is what holds a project together. Own it.hashtag#DocumentControl hashtag#ConstructionManagement hashtag#Omega365 hashtag#Aconex hashtag#Procore hashtag#CareerAdvice hashtag#ProjectManagement hashtag#EDMS

When NVS Fails on ESP32â€¦ LittleFS to the Rescue! In one of our recent IoT projects, we ran into a tricky issue after rolling out a new firmware update (OTA) to all our ESP32-based devices. Out of nearly 30,000 units, about 100 started acting weirdâ€”some configs didnâ€™t load properly, and things just didnâ€™t add up.After digging into it, we found the root cause: we had increased the EEPROM size from 2KB to 5KB, and it turned out NVS couldnâ€™t handle it well on all devices.When we scanned the full memory, we saw corruption issues in those affected devices. ğŸ˜¬So, together with my teammates, we decided to shift our strategy.We moved our data and device configurations from NVS to SPIFFS using LittleFS ---> and it worked like a charm! ğŸ‹  Everything became stable and clean again.ğŸ” A quick takeaway:Sometimes NVS isn't the best fit for larger or dynamic data. LittleFS gave us the reliability we needed for this scale of deployment.Just wanted to share in case someone else is hitting a similar wallâ€”hope it saves you some time!hashtag#ESP32 hashtag#IoT hashtag#LittleFS hashtag#NVS hashtag#SPIFFS hashtag#FirmwareUpdate hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MemoryManagement hashtag#TechFix

"ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙÙ„ Ø±ÙÙ‘Ø¨ÙÙ‘ Ø²ÙØ¯Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù‹Ø§" â€“ Ø³ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø·Ù‡ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© 114ğŸ”§ MCSA Project 5: Deploying a Multi-Site Domain Controller with IFM and NIC Teaming â€“ A Real-World SimulationIâ€™ve just completed my fifth and most comprehensive MCSA project so far â€” a full-scale enterprise-level deployment involving multiple sites, advanced domain replication, and optimized server communication. Here's a breakdown of what I implemented:1ï¸âƒ£ Creating IFM Media for Domain Replication To simulate a real-world "Install From Media" (IFM) scenario, I generated a custom IFM package containing the Active Directory database and SYSVOL. Using ntdsutil via elevated CMD, I navigated to the IFM module and executed the command: create sysvol full C:\ifm This IFM folder allows a new domain controller to be promoted without replicating over the WAN â€” ideal for branch offices.2ï¸âƒ£ Lab Structure and Configuration I designed two sites: Cairo and Mansoura.Cairoâ€™s Server 2016 was configured as a Primary Domain Controller (PDC) and joined with a Windows 10 client in the same domain.The network was fully connected (pingable), and proper domain resolution was ensured through DNS configuration.I added a second Ethernet adapter and implemented NIC Teaming, enhancing bandwidth and redundancy.ğŸ’¡ NIC Teaming Benefits:Increased throughput via load balancingNetwork fault toleranceSeamless connectivity in case of NIC failure3ï¸âƒ£ Cloning and SID Regeneration for New Site To prepare the Mansoura site, I cloned the Cairo server and changed its SID using Sysprep to avoid domain conflicts. Upon reboot, the server was demoted to a Workgroup â€” a critical step in separating domain identity between sites.4ï¸âƒ£ Establishing Trust & Promoting the ADCI reconnected the Mansoura server to the Cairo network.Ensured two-way communication was functional (DNS + pingable).Installed Active Directory Domain Services on Mansoura's server.Promoted it as an Additional Domain Controller (ADC) using credentials from the existing domain (tshoot\administrator).Selected Mansoura as the site and enabled both DNS and Global Catalog roles.5ï¸âƒ£ IFM-Based User Replication Post-promotion, I imported the users from the previously created IFM folder. âœ… Users created in Cairo were instantly visible in Mansoura â€” proving successful replication.6ï¸âƒ£ Final TouchesRenamed servers accordingly: PDC (Cairo) and ADC (Mansoura)Disabled firewalls to avoid blocking replication or communicationInstalled VMware Tools to enhance performance and integrationğŸ’¼ This project was a deep dive into multi-site domain architecture, replication, network optimization, and disaster recovery readiness â€” and honestly, it felt like managing an enterprise-level infrastructure.Always striving to learn by doing, and this one was a milestone.Mohamed Tarek Zyad Waleed Elzyat Ali Khaled hashtag#MCSA hashtag#ActiveDirectory hashtag#Sysadmin hashtag#WindowsServer2016 hashtag#Networking hashtag#ITInfrastructure hashtag#NICTeaming hashtag#InstallFromMedia hashtag#LinkedInLearning hashtag#SysadminLife hashtag#MCSE hashtag#ITProjects

Contract Grace Period: Express or Implied?A grace period in contractsâ€”like extra days to pay or deliver without penaltyâ€”is usually an express term, not implied. It must be clearly stated in the contract to be enforceable. Rarely, it may be implied by consistent practice or industry norms, but donâ€™t count on it.Always review and include grace period clauses upfront to avoid disputes later!

Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Long ago, when I started my journey as a developer, Java was the first serious language I committed to.It was trending.It was not â€œeasy.â€It demanded commitment with discipline.It raised the bar of programming standards.Back then, most of the people moving to Java were coming from C or C++ backgrounds. To be productive in C++, you had to be a good programmer, having good command on OOP concepts especially polymorphism. In addition to OOP, you couldnâ€™t fake your way through memory management, pointers, templates and object slicing. Java came in as a more structured, opinionated language, but still demanded solid fundamentals just like C++. In fact, Iâ€™d argue, and IMHO, you rarely see an average programmer doing good in Java. It exposes gaps in your thoughts, and demand a better programming aptitude, not just for syntax, but also for development design especially taking ownership of your code with integration & unit tests.Java developers are often rated as having stronger software engineering and system design skills in hiring benchmarks, especially in enterprise and backend domains.Java doesnâ€™t teach you to just get things done. It teaches you how to think, how to structure, and how to build something that wonâ€™t collapse six months from now.I happily admit and gives credit to Java for my growth, it taught me: - Real-world modeling with OOP & OOAD - Contracts matter with method overloading & overriding (Polymorphism) - Building objects relationships in real world based on class hierarchy using inheritance or object agregation or composition based on loose or tight coupling. - Abstraction & encapsulation to write better code visibility & reusability. - Think yout code by applying design patterns especially "Gang of Four" & design principles like SOLID, KISS, DRY, YAGNI or etc. - The power of the JVM and why type safety matters at scaleAfter working across Pakistan, Japan, US (Remote) and Germany, leading engineering at global companies, migrating systems to the cloud, and building scalable platforms. I still find Javaâ€™s influence in how I think and design. Itâ€™s a legacy of good practises in action.A Stack Overflow Developer Survey still places Java among the most used and loved backend languages, even with all the new frameworks and languages in the ecosystem.For new learners or budding programmers, donâ€™t be discouraged by its rules or verbosity. Those same things will shape you into a better software engineer.Build systems, but also build your legacy.hashtag#java hashtag#programming hashtag#softwaredevelopment hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#developermindset hashtag#techleadership hashtag#cleancode hashtag#engineeringgrowth hashtag#growthmindset hashtag#objectorienteddesign hashtag#objectorientedprogramming hashtag#softwarecraftsmanship hashtag#lifelonglearner

If you're a new document controller, here are some practical tips to help you grow faster, avoid common mistakes, and earn the trust of your team:âœ… 1. Understand the Project Structure FirstBefore diving into filing documents, take time to understand the project's phases, key disciplines, and document types. This makes organizing and tagging much easier.âœ… 2. Naming Conventions Are Not Just FormalitiesFollow them strictly. They're essential for traceability and version controlâ€”and can save hours during audits or disputes.âœ… 3. Keep Your Registers Clean and UpdatedWhether you're using Excel or an EDMS, your logs are the heart of document tracking. Incomplete logs cause confusionâ€”be diligent.âœ… 4. Communicate with Engineers and DesignersYou're not just pushing papers. You're managing information flow. Ask questions, clarify document statuses, and don't hesitate to request re-submissions if something doesn't follow procedure.âœ… 5. Learn the Tools DeeplyDonâ€™t just "use" Aconex or Omega365â€”master it. Explore shortcuts, batch processing, and advanced features to save time and reduce errors.âœ… 6. Always Back Up. Always.Even with cloud systems, keep daily backups of registers and key documents. Technology failsâ€”discipline doesnâ€™t.âœ… 7. Be the Guardian of ComplianceYour role ensures that the right people get the right information at the right timeâ€”with full traceability. Thatâ€™s powerful.ğŸ¯ To all the fresh document controllers out there: Your job may feel behind-the-scenes, but your work is what holds a project together. Own it.hashtag#DocumentControl hashtag#ConstructionManagement hashtag#Omega365 hashtag#Aconex hashtag#Procore hashtag#CareerAdvice hashtag#ProjectManagement hashtag#EDMS

When NVS Fails on ESP32â€¦ LittleFS to the Rescue! In one of our recent IoT projects, we ran into a tricky issue after rolling out a new firmware update (OTA) to all our ESP32-based devices. Out of nearly 30,000 units, about 100 started acting weirdâ€”some configs didnâ€™t load properly, and things just didnâ€™t add up.After digging into it, we found the root cause: we had increased the EEPROM size from 2KB to 5KB, and it turned out NVS couldnâ€™t handle it well on all devices.When we scanned the full memory, we saw corruption issues in those affected devices. ğŸ˜¬So, together with my teammates, we decided to shift our strategy.We moved our data and device configurations from NVS to SPIFFS using LittleFS ---> and it worked like a charm! ğŸ‹  Everything became stable and clean again.ğŸ” A quick takeaway:Sometimes NVS isn't the best fit for larger or dynamic data. LittleFS gave us the reliability we needed for this scale of deployment.Just wanted to share in case someone else is hitting a similar wallâ€”hope it saves you some time!hashtag#ESP32 hashtag#IoT hashtag#LittleFS hashtag#NVS hashtag#SPIFFS hashtag#FirmwareUpdate hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MemoryManagement hashtag#TechFix

"ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙÙ„ Ø±ÙÙ‘Ø¨ÙÙ‘ Ø²ÙØ¯Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù‹Ø§" â€“ Ø³ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø·Ù‡ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© 114ğŸ”§ MCSA Project 5: Deploying a Multi-Site Domain Controller with IFM and NIC Teaming â€“ A Real-World SimulationIâ€™ve just completed my fifth and most comprehensive MCSA project so far â€” a full-scale enterprise-level deployment involving multiple sites, advanced domain replication, and optimized server communication. Here's a breakdown of what I implemented:1ï¸âƒ£ Creating IFM Media for Domain Replication To simulate a real-world "Install From Media" (IFM) scenario, I generated a custom IFM package containing the Active Directory database and SYSVOL. Using ntdsutil via elevated CMD, I navigated to the IFM module and executed the command: create sysvol full C:\ifm This IFM folder allows a new domain controller to be promoted without replicating over the WAN â€” ideal for branch offices.2ï¸âƒ£ Lab Structure and Configuration I designed two sites: Cairo and Mansoura.Cairoâ€™s Server 2016 was configured as a Primary Domain Controller (PDC) and joined with a Windows 10 client in the same domain.The network was fully connected (pingable), and proper domain resolution was ensured through DNS configuration.I added a second Ethernet adapter and implemented NIC Teaming, enhancing bandwidth and redundancy.ğŸ’¡ NIC Teaming Benefits:Increased throughput via load balancingNetwork fault toleranceSeamless connectivity in case of NIC failure3ï¸âƒ£ Cloning and SID Regeneration for New Site To prepare the Mansoura site, I cloned the Cairo server and changed its SID using Sysprep to avoid domain conflicts. Upon reboot, the server was demoted to a Workgroup â€” a critical step in separating domain identity between sites.4ï¸âƒ£ Establishing Trust & Promoting the ADCI reconnected the Mansoura server to the Cairo network.Ensured two-way communication was functional (DNS + pingable).Installed Active Directory Domain Services on Mansoura's server.Promoted it as an Additional Domain Controller (ADC) using credentials from the existing domain (tshoot\administrator).Selected Mansoura as the site and enabled both DNS and Global Catalog roles.5ï¸âƒ£ IFM-Based User Replication Post-promotion, I imported the users from the previously created IFM folder. âœ… Users created in Cairo were instantly visible in Mansoura â€” proving successful replication.6ï¸âƒ£ Final TouchesRenamed servers accordingly: PDC (Cairo) and ADC (Mansoura)Disabled firewalls to avoid blocking replication or communicationInstalled VMware Tools to enhance performance and integrationğŸ’¼ This project was a deep dive into multi-site domain architecture, replication, network optimization, and disaster recovery readiness â€” and honestly, it felt like managing an enterprise-level infrastructure.Always striving to learn by doing, and this one was a milestone.Mohamed Tarek Zyad Waleed Elzyat Ali Khaled hashtag#MCSA hashtag#ActiveDirectory hashtag#Sysadmin hashtag#WindowsServer2016 hashtag#Networking hashtag#ITInfrastructure hashtag#NICTeaming hashtag#InstallFromMedia hashtag#LinkedInLearning hashtag#SysadminLife hashtag#MCSE hashtag#ITProjects

Rarely, it may be implied by consistent practice or industry norms, but donâ€™t count on it.Always review and include grace period clauses upfront to avoid disputes later!

Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Long ago, when I started my journey as a developer, Java was the first serious language I committed to.It was trending.It was not â€œeasy.â€It demanded commitment with discipline.It raised the bar of programming standards.Back then, most of the people moving to Java were coming from C or C++ backgrounds. To be productive in C++, you had to be a good programmer, having good command on OOP concepts especially polymorphism. In addition to OOP, you couldnâ€™t fake your way through memory management, pointers, templates and object slicing. Java came in as a more structured, opinionated language, but still demanded solid fundamentals just like C++. In fact, Iâ€™d argue, and IMHO, you rarely see an average programmer doing good in Java. It exposes gaps in your thoughts, and demand a better programming aptitude, not just for syntax, but also for development design especially taking ownership of your code with integration & unit tests.Java developers are often rated as having stronger software engineering and system design skills in hiring benchmarks, especially in enterprise and backend domains.Java doesnâ€™t teach you to just get things done. It teaches you how to think, how to structure, and how to build something that wonâ€™t collapse six months from now.I happily admit and gives credit to Java for my growth, it taught me: - Real-world modeling with OOP & OOAD - Contracts matter with method overloading & overriding (Polymorphism) - Building objects relationships in real world based on class hierarchy using inheritance or object agregation or composition based on loose or tight coupling. - Abstraction & encapsulation to write better code visibility & reusability. - Think yout code by applying design patterns especially "Gang of Four" & design principles like SOLID, KISS, DRY, YAGNI or etc. - The power of the JVM and why type safety matters at scaleAfter working across Pakistan, Japan, US (Remote) and Germany, leading engineering at global companies, migrating systems to the cloud, and building scalable platforms. I still find Javaâ€™s influence in how I think and design. Itâ€™s a legacy of good practises in action.A Stack Overflow Developer Survey still places Java among the most used and loved backend languages, even with all the new frameworks and languages in the ecosystem.For new learners or budding programmers, donâ€™t be discouraged by its rules or verbosity. Those same things will shape you into a better software engineer.Build systems, but also build your legacy.hashtag#java hashtag#programming hashtag#softwaredevelopment hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#developermindset hashtag#techleadership hashtag#cleancode hashtag#engineeringgrowth hashtag#growthmindset hashtag#objectorienteddesign hashtag#objectorientedprogramming hashtag#softwarecraftsmanship hashtag#lifelonglearner

If you're a new document controller, here are some practical tips to help you grow faster, avoid common mistakes, and earn the trust of your team:âœ… 1. Understand the Project Structure FirstBefore diving into filing documents, take time to understand the project's phases, key disciplines, and document types. This makes organizing and tagging much easier.âœ… 2. Naming Conventions Are Not Just FormalitiesFollow them strictly. They're essential for traceability and version controlâ€”and can save hours during audits or disputes.âœ… 3. Keep Your Registers Clean and UpdatedWhether you're using Excel or an EDMS, your logs are the heart of document tracking. Incomplete logs cause confusionâ€”be diligent.âœ… 4. Communicate with Engineers and DesignersYou're not just pushing papers. You're managing information flow. Ask questions, clarify document statuses, and don't hesitate to request re-submissions if something doesn't follow procedure.âœ… 5. Learn the Tools DeeplyDonâ€™t just "use" Aconex or Omega365â€”master it. Explore shortcuts, batch processing, and advanced features to save time and reduce errors.âœ… 6. Always Back Up. Always.Even with cloud systems, keep daily backups of registers and key documents. Technology failsâ€”discipline doesnâ€™t.âœ… 7. Be the Guardian of ComplianceYour role ensures that the right people get the right information at the right timeâ€”with full traceability. Thatâ€™s powerful.ğŸ¯ To all the fresh document controllers out there: Your job may feel behind-the-scenes, but your work is what holds a project together. Own it.hashtag#DocumentControl hashtag#ConstructionManagement hashtag#Omega365 hashtag#Aconex hashtag#Procore hashtag#CareerAdvice hashtag#ProjectManagement hashtag#EDMS

When NVS Fails on ESP32â€¦ LittleFS to the Rescue! In one of our recent IoT projects, we ran into a tricky issue after rolling out a new firmware update (OTA) to all our ESP32-based devices. Out of nearly 30,000 units, about 100 started acting weirdâ€”some configs didnâ€™t load properly, and things just didnâ€™t add up.After digging into it, we found the root cause: we had increased the EEPROM size from 2KB to 5KB, and it turned out NVS couldnâ€™t handle it well on all devices.When we scanned the full memory, we saw corruption issues in those affected devices. ğŸ˜¬So, together with my teammates, we decided to shift our strategy.We moved our data and device configurations from NVS to SPIFFS using LittleFS ---> and it worked like a charm! ğŸ‹  Everything became stable and clean again.ğŸ” A quick takeaway:Sometimes NVS isn't the best fit for larger or dynamic data. LittleFS gave us the reliability we needed for this scale of deployment.Just wanted to share in case someone else is hitting a similar wallâ€”hope it saves you some time!hashtag#ESP32 hashtag#IoT hashtag#LittleFS hashtag#NVS hashtag#SPIFFS hashtag#FirmwareUpdate hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MemoryManagement hashtag#TechFix

"ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙÙ„ Ø±ÙÙ‘Ø¨ÙÙ‘ Ø²ÙØ¯Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù‹Ø§" â€“ Ø³ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø·Ù‡ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© 114ğŸ”§ MCSA Project 5: Deploying a Multi-Site Domain Controller with IFM and NIC Teaming â€“ A Real-World SimulationIâ€™ve just completed my fifth and most comprehensive MCSA project so far â€” a full-scale enterprise-level deployment involving multiple sites, advanced domain replication, and optimized server communication. Here's a breakdown of what I implemented:1ï¸âƒ£ Creating IFM Media for Domain Replication To simulate a real-world "Install From Media" (IFM) scenario, I generated a custom IFM package containing the Active Directory database and SYSVOL. Using ntdsutil via elevated CMD, I navigated to the IFM module and executed the command: create sysvol full C:\ifm This IFM folder allows a new domain controller to be promoted without replicating over the WAN â€” ideal for branch offices.2ï¸âƒ£ Lab Structure and Configuration I designed two sites: Cairo and Mansoura.Cairoâ€™s Server 2016 was configured as a Primary Domain Controller (PDC) and joined with a Windows 10 client in the same domain.The network was fully connected (pingable), and proper domain resolution was ensured through DNS configuration.I added a second Ethernet adapter and implemented NIC Teaming, enhancing bandwidth and redundancy.ğŸ’¡ NIC Teaming Benefits:Increased throughput via load balancingNetwork fault toleranceSeamless connectivity in case of NIC failure3ï¸âƒ£ Cloning and SID Regeneration for New Site To prepare the Mansoura site, I cloned the Cairo server and changed its SID using Sysprep to avoid domain conflicts. Upon reboot, the server was demoted to a Workgroup â€” a critical step in separating domain identity between sites.4ï¸âƒ£ Establishing Trust & Promoting the ADCI reconnected the Mansoura server to the Cairo network.Ensured two-way communication was functional (DNS + pingable).Installed Active Directory Domain Services on Mansoura's server.Promoted it as an Additional Domain Controller (ADC) using credentials from the existing domain (tshoot\administrator).Selected Mansoura as the site and enabled both DNS and Global Catalog roles.5ï¸âƒ£ IFM-Based User Replication Post-promotion, I imported the users from the previously created IFM folder. âœ… Users created in Cairo were instantly visible in Mansoura â€” proving successful replication.6ï¸âƒ£ Final TouchesRenamed servers accordingly: PDC (Cairo) and ADC (Mansoura)Disabled firewalls to avoid blocking replication or communicationInstalled VMware Tools to enhance performance and integrationğŸ’¼ This project was a deep dive into multi-site domain architecture, replication, network optimization, and disaster recovery readiness â€” and honestly, it felt like managing an enterprise-level infrastructure.Always striving to learn by doing, and this one was a milestone.Mohamed Tarek Zyad Waleed Elzyat Ali Khaled hashtag#MCSA hashtag#ActiveDirectory hashtag#Sysadmin hashtag#WindowsServer2016 hashtag#Networking hashtag#ITInfrastructure hashtag#NICTeaming hashtag#InstallFromMedia hashtag#LinkedInLearning hashtag#SysadminLife hashtag#MCSE hashtag#ITProjects

Contract Grace Period: Express or Implied?A grace period in contractsâ€”like extra days to pay or deliver without penaltyâ€”is usually an express term, not implied. It must be clearly stated in the contract to be enforceable. Rarely, it may be implied by consistent practice or industry norms, but donâ€™t count on it.Always review and include grace period clauses upfront to avoid disputes later!

Securing APIs with Spring Security & OAuth2Securing APIs is crucial in todayâ€™s digital world as they are key to web, mobile apps, and microservices. Spring Security and OAuth2 provide a solution to protect APIs and ensure that only authorized users can access sensitive data.This guide explains how to secure Spring Boot APIs with Spring Security and OAuth2.Understanding Spring Security & OAuth2Spring Security: A framework offering features like authentication, authorization, and protection against attacks. It integrates with Spring Boot.OAuth2: An open standard for token-based authentication, allowing third-party apps access without exposing credentials, ensuring only authorized clients access protected resources.Key Concepts of OAuth2Authorization Server: Issues access tokens after authentication.Resource Server: Hosts resources and validates tokens.Access Token: Short-lived token for authentication.Refresh Token: Long-lived token for obtaining new access tokens.Scopes: Defines access level granted by the token.Steps to Secure APIs with Spring Security & OAuth2Set Up Your Spring Boot Project: Add dependencies to pom.xml:<dependency> <groupId>org.springframework.boot</groupId> <artifactId>spring-boot-starter-oauth2-resource-server</artifactId></dependency><dependency> <groupId>https://lnkd.in/dWp4pGEf</groupId> <artifactId>spring-security-oauth2-client</artifactId></dependency><dependency> <groupId>org.springframework.boot</groupId> <artifactId>spring-boot-starter-web</artifactId></dependency>Configure Spring Security: Set up as a Resource Server:spring: security: oauth2: resourceserver: jwt: issuer-uri: https://lnkd.in/dUnxptJkSet Up Authorization Server: Configure OAuth2 login:spring: security: oauth2: client: registration: google: client-id: YOUR_GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID client-secret: YOUR_GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET scope: profile, email redirect-uri: "{baseUrl}/login/oauth2/code/{registrationId}"Protect Your APIs: Secure endpoints by requiring authentication:@RestControllerpublic class SecuredController { @GetMapping("/user-info") public String getUserInfo(@AuthenticationPrincipal OAuth2User principal) { return "Hello, " + principal.getAttribute("name"); }}Testing and Debugging: Use Postman to test OAuth2 and check logs for issues.ConclusionSpring Security with OAuth2 secures your Spring Boot APIs using token-based authentication. It integrates easily with OAuth2 providers, offering a flexible solution for securing modern APIs.
